author: Chief Court Reporter Sean Fewster
title: SA Judge Barry Beazley speaks out against perception on meth-driving acquittal of Leah Jane Lenarczyk |
text:
A JUDGE who acquitted a drug-using mother, who ran down a boy, of dangerous driving has spoken out against a public perception that he was in any way condoning methylamphetamine.
During sentencing submissions in the District Court today, Judge Barry Beazley took the unusual step of speaking about his controversial acquittal of Leah Jane Lenarczyk.
He said The Advertiser had correctly recorded his verdict in Lenarczyk’s case, and his reasons for it, when it exclusively reported the decision earlier this month.
“Anybody who could possibly believe that I was in some way suggesting it was OK to drive with methylamphetamine (in their system) could not have possibly read or properly read the verdict I gave,” he said.
Leah Jane Lenarczyk outside court for a previous hearing. Today, she left court with her face covered by a scarf.
“At no stage have I suggested or even thought that the use of drugs while driving is OK.
“There should be no suggestion otherwise that I was suggesting I was ‘OK’ with it.”
READ JUDGE BEAZLEY’S FULL REMARKS
Lenarczyk, 39, was charged with one aggravated count of causing serious harm by dangerous driving.
At trial, prosecutors alleged she had just picked up her own three children from school when she ran a red light and hit Nickolas Falco, 12, at a Salisbury Heights pedestrian crossing.
It was the fifth time Lenarczyk had driven while unregistered, uninsured and without a licence, and she had completed a good behaviour bond for prior offending just four months earlier.
Nickolas sustained a broken leg, collapsed lung, abdominal injuries and skull fractures.
In his verdict, Judge Beazley acquitted Lenarczyk of the major offence and instead found her guilty of the lesser charge of driving without due care.
He ruled prosecutors had not proved, beyond reasonable doubt, the “mid-level” recording of methylamphetamine in her system caused any adverse effect on her driving.
He said that, based on medical evidence, it may have had “a positive effect” instead.
Judge Beazley’s ruling angered Nickolas’ mother, Jaki Watson, who said her son was “haunted” and the verdict should be challenged on appeal .
It also prompted SA Police to hold a media conference, where a senior officer spoke about the dangers of using drugs while driving, and generated widespread community debate.
Jaki Watson and Nickolas Falco. Picture: Mark Brake. Source: News Corp Australia
Today, Nickolas’ victim impact statement was read to the court.
In it, Nickolas wrote he had once been a happy BMX rider who was confident to attempt tricks, but was now a frightened, bullied, anxious young man.
“I felt paranoid and curious about who this person (Lenarczyk) was, why she did this to me, and why me,” he wrote.
“I started to become more angry, moody and stressed ... I have angry outbursts ... I once smashed my expensive laptop with my crutches ... I still get very angry at the smallest things.”
His words reduced Lenarczyk, who sat in the dock of the court, to tears and she continued to cry as Ms Watson read her victim impact statement aloud.
Ms Watson said Nickolas now suffered from post-traumatic stress, struggled to come to terms with his multiple scars and had broken a bone in his hand by punching a wall in anger.
“I’m very disappointed with the verdict and believe it sends a message to the community that you can drive while on drugs,” she said.
She then addressed Lenarczyk personally, asking her “what right” she had to be on the road while drugged “in the first place”.
“As a mother I don’t understand why you would put your own children at risk ... what gives you the right to do what you like with drugs in your system?” she said.
“You had eight seconds to respond to those lights, why didn’t you stop?
“Your selfish actions almost cost my son his life and, in many ways, you have taken part of him ... I don’t forgive you for what you have done.
“A good behaviour bond is not enough — you should go to prison.”
The court also heard a community impact statement from Michael O’Connell, the Commissioner for Victims’ Rights.
He said there was “no safe level” of methylamphetamine in a person’s system and that road laws should be amended to “zero tolerance, zero level” of the drug, even if prescribed.
District Court Judge Barry Beazley. Source: News Limited
Judge Beazley thanked Mr O’Connell for his comments, calling them “common sense” and “entirely appropriate”.
“What I did do in my reasons was base my decision not upon my view of methylamphetamine but my perception of shortcomings in the evidence,” he said.
“I relied upon two leading experts in Australia as to what the effect would be ... that was the basis of my decision.”
Adam Richards, for Lenarczyk, said his client was on the road that day because she “needed” to take her children to school, and they lived too far away to walk.
He said she was in the midst of moving house at the time, and a friend who was helping her had given her methylamphetamine.
“It had only been for the purpose of trying to keep her energy levels up so she could continue working (on the move),” he said.
Mr Richards said Lenarczyk had been “devastated” by the incident and her children were “distraught” because they had witnessed both it and their mother’s arrest.
As he spoke, Ms Watson stood up and left the court.
Leah Jane Lenarczyk outside the District Court before a previous hearing. Source: News Corp Australia
Mr Richards read an apology on Lenarczyk’s behalf, in which she wrote she “could not emphasise enough” her sorrow, regret, remorse or contrition.
“I worry, knowing what pain I have caused (Nickolas) ... I struggle with the anguish and frustration that his family must feel,” she wrote.
“I’m not a bad person ... (this was) an error in judgment, one mistake, one instance in time I wish could be reversed.
“That shouldn’t be enough to destroy more lives and tear apart a loving family.”
Mr Richards urged the court to suspend any jail term imposed upon his client.
“It’s a terrible reality for everyone of us who uses the roads that accidents happen — that’s what this is, an accident,” he said.
“An accident is an accident, it’s a terrible thing for Nickolas, but it was an accident and nothing more.”
Charles Wright, prosecuting, said Lenarczyk’s conduct went much further than a mere accident when viewed in the context of her offending history.
“It’s abundantly clear she needs a strong deterrent in the form of an immediate custodial sentence,” he said.
“She has been given fines, licence disqualifications and bonds, yet she continues to flout and show blatant disregard for the law and flagrant disregard for court orders.
“Her prospects for rehabilitation are bleak.”
Judge Beazley remanded Lenarczyk on continuing bail for sentencing in two weeks.
She left court, accompanied by supporters, with her face covered by a scarf.
